Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @Fab√ò    Yes it has been awhile,  been just grinding away.  I believe I have found a way to create a asset backed stablecoin that doesn‚Äôt require much legally.  I believe it can help a lot of the areas we need to improve in,  I wrote a little bit about it in the jl777 channel.  I‚Äôll copypaste it over here.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: ‚ÄúI have in mind using these tokens to represent warehouse receipts used to claim stored goods, specifically standardized commodities but it can and will be expanded to other goods as well.  If these tokens can be atomic swapped with coins like I described above ,  this can effectively solve liquidity issue with Atomicdex, as well as other benefits , in the form many additional chains added to the ecosystem to accommodate other interests ( a different chain with its own tokens for each country or city or warehouse location for instance ) .  Beyond stablecoins(warehouse receipts ),  many chains ( fees to Komodo ),  liquidity ( more things for KMD to trade against )  it provides the ecosystem with a form of ‚Äúgood‚Äù money ( Gresham law reference )  which can siphon from even other coins and their liquidity.‚Äù

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: I would like to discuss this with you and @ca333 @noashh#2802  @Bitcoin Benny  @jl777c and others.  I believe this could be a unicorn project.  However it is well beyond the scope of just one person,  there are some things technologically that need done ( and need done regardless of this project ) ,  on the business/legal end and physical end as well,  let alone if the parties involved wish to do a fundraising offering.   From my deep delve into the UCC and federal and state regulations over the last few days ,  it does not appear there are any legal quagmires like other types of stablecoins .  Being not a currency itself but rather a document of title and is not a security  as it is not an investment contract ( passes Howey) ,  it‚Äôs not algorithmically based as it is backed by collateral .  I am seeking out legal counsel on this .

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content:
we'd be willing to work with @polycryptoblog along these lines and incorporate into the LUMBER brand, but there isn't much point in discussing if the budget is pegged too low as well as a good understanding of regulatory/legal risk and the costs of maintaining a legal team.

Another venture I'd be willing to be a part of is "Project Marine Iguana"; i.e  establish a self-sustaining cryptomining farm using windpower on the island of Malta. The mined crypto could be distributed to coin hodlers and/or fiat reserves could be built up by reselling the electricity locally while building longterm strategic relationships in the region.

Author: skitout#8659
Content:
Hej ! I been thinking about an idea, and as VC would be users, I post it here for feedback

Especially in early phases of projects, there is sometime a bit of a chicken and egg problem when it comes to funding. That is where ‚ÄúConditional Automatic Funding‚Äù (CAF) could kick in. Investors put some money on the table and verifiable objectives are set. The project automatically gets the money if it delivers, otherwise investors automatically get their money back.

Investors derisk their investment while scooping project earlier. The project boosts its credibility, feel secure and focus on what‚Äôs matter: delivering. It could be used for ‚Äúclassic‚Äù startup funding (e.g. with SAFE) or for crypto projects.

Seems to me (a non tech guy) a MVP based on Komodo, would be relatively ‚Äúeasy‚Äù to develop, possibly with a centralized oracle at first (like EY or PWC).

This would also get early stage projects and investors to connect with the Komodo ecosystem: that could make a lot of sense on a marketing perspective.
